CHAPTER 2 EUROPE'S MAJOR RAILWAYS The dominant characteristic of the rail administrations within Europe and Scandinavia is that they are state owned enterprises. The Channel Tunnel will provide an important future exception. There are some international institutions and operators, described in Chapter 8. Others include the Union Internationale de Chemins de Fer (UIC), which has existed for many years, acting as an international forum for the exchange of technical information, agreement of standards, and provision of a clearing house for allocation of international revenues. There are several organisations formed and funded by the railways to facilitate international passenger and freight operations. Eurofima is a jointly funded railway venture which makes loans for the purchase of rolling stock. The European Commission part funds some railway investment projects but, for the foreseeable future, the railways of Europe and Scandinavia are likely to remain national enterprises. Historically, national ownership of this specialised mode of transport, the associated creation of monopolies and the general decline in market share created problems for national governments. Although the major concern was the increase in funding requirements, another was the stress inherent in interacting effectively with technical and supply oriented organisations. During the last two decades both government and railway administrations have sought to evolve better bases for the clarification of objectives and the specification of funding requirements. In respect of the latter, there was a desire to reduce the requirement and to ensure that in future there was a defined return on the funding. There are a number of intermingled themes which are reflected within the contemporary arrangements between the public authorities and their railway administrations: • the preparation of plans by the railways for consideration and approval by ministers; • the concept that the railways will at least break even on operating account, after agreed levels of subsidy support or compensation have been included; • the need for subsidy or support should be declining or constant rather than a rising requirement over time; • the railways should be given performance standards and tasks by their national governments; there is, naturally, an orientation to the financial aspects, though some governments, such as the Dutch and the German, also set non-financial objectives; • the internal organisation and management information systems of the railways should be structured so as to ensure that the requirements of the states can be realised and their achievements monitored; • there are components of rail markets for which state support is not an a priori requirement; the most commonly recognised components are international passenger operations, long distance passenger operations, freight and parcel services; • in those market sectors within which rail operations do not qualify for subsidy, relative freedom should be given to the railways to develop market oriented strategies and the disciplines of the market should be allowed to determine pricing policies; • issues of equity for the railways arise from the fact that public authorities fund the infrastructure for their competition — highways, airports and air traffic control systems, for example; the users do not necessarily pay the full cost whereas the railways traditionally have borne the costs of the maintenance and renewal of their infrastructure;

• the funding of historic debts by interest charges or other payments undermines or distorts the current financial structures of the railways. Some of these themes are present in the proposed EC Council Directive which is discussed more fully in Chapter 4. All, in practice, have had a role in the restructuring of many of the railway · systems in the 1980s. They can be observed in the following brief descriptions of seven of the railways of Europe and Scandinavia. SNCF (FRANCE) The structure of SNCF was changed in 1982 giving it a new status similar to Electricité de France. The government is its owner and appoints the chairman and general manager. It has a monopoly of the provision of rail services in France. The board of SNCF is made up of government, trade union and user representatives. There are deputy managing directors with specific responsibilities: • economic and financial; • technical; • personnel; • research and development. In 1990 four business sectors reporting to the general manager were created: • passenger; • freight; • parcels; • Paris suburban services. It is anticipated that these business sectors will have full financial accountability and will purchase services and resources from the deputy managing directors. There is also a new post of deputy director general with the primary task of gearing SNCF to changing market conditions. SNCF has an accumulated deficit of £10.1 bn which is being addressed through special provisions. The state has a contract with SNCF which requires that the railway balances its accounts annually after receipt of statutory supports which are specific. For 1991 these were: £ mn Infrastructure 1,045 Pensions 1,400 Compensation for socially reduced tariffs 160 Regional passenger services 370 The 1990-94 contract makes joint provision for investment as follows: SNCF State £ mn £ mn Historic* railway 3,800 550 TGV infrastructure & rolling stock 4,400 200 Paris suburban 1,040 545 ' Pre-TGV. In 1988 SNCF operating revenue was around £5 bn supplemented by state and local authority support of rather less than £1.5 bn.

SNCF has the capability to meet the targets set by the contract as was demonstrated in 1989 by its achievement in matching the requirements of the task set in the 1985-89 contract. Nevertheless SNCF does not enjoy full freedom with respect to the setting of passenger fares. In general they can only be increased in total in line with expected levels of inflation (though this provision does not apply to TGV services). DB (FORMER WEST GERMANY) Herr Rudolf Richter, representing DB in the UK, described DB as "an essential part of the federal government administrative structure and extremely close financial, political and legal links exist between the two". In 1982 the state appointed a new board of management with a mandate to alter the fundamental operating environment and to improve the public perception of the rail services. This administration produced a new railway strategy called "DB 90". Its fundamental goal was the change in the role of the railway from government monopoly, providing an across the board public service, into an innovative market oriented transport undertaking. There are four major elements to the "DB 90" strategy: • improving the railway service; • increasing competitive measures; • expanding the rail share of the market; • encouraging cooperation with affiliates and branches in order to provide a more comprehensive travel service. Between 1982 and 1989 DB was able to invest £13.5 bn and reduce its staff from 321,000 to 238,000. By the end of 1988 the accumulated deficit was around £14.5 bn. In 1989 the federal government agreed to take over £4.25 bn of the deficit and to participate in funding infrastructure costs. DB was required by the end of 1990 to produce a detailed statement of its track and operating costs. The state and local governments are expected to make a contribution towards a proportion of the latter. Between 1990 and 1994 investment in routes, rolling stock and facilities is planned to total £11.5 bn and by the year 2000 the plan envisages a total investment of £20 bn. DB is developing a high speed passenger network involving the construction of new lines, first incorporated in the Federal Infrastructure Plan (BVWP '85). The new lines consist of 800 km of new track and there is an associated upgrading of 3,700 km of existing lines. The new line construction is funded by federal grants. Every year the proposed plan has to be agreed with the federal government. DB has a certain degree of pricing freedom. The InterCity services are moving into profit and the second grade of service, Interregio, which has been improved progressively, is showing improved financial performance. DB's personnel are federal employees and thus it does not have the freedom to determine pay and conditions. However, it receives compensation for some of these costs, together with offsets for the costs of provision of regional, urban and rural services. The government is progressively moving towards local funding for the latter. In July 1990 the federal government appointed a commission in response to DB's request for:

• a financial structure more acceptable for entrepreneurial activity; • tax harmonisation; • contractual agreements; • federal assumption of responsibility for infrastructure. The commission will report in 1991. Its tasks are essentially: • to define the role of DB in national and international markets; • to define and limit the responsibilities for public or community services; • to define DB's business and economic responsibilities; • to set out the conditions for a rational and requirement specific fulfilment ot tasks by DB. Reorganisation and restructuring of DB has moved at a slower pace than in the case of SNCF and BR. It is, however, moving in a similar direction in many ways. In March 1990 Dr Ing Reiner Golke, chairman of the board of directors of DB, stated that DB and DR (the former East German state railway system) were planning for an eventual single German railway to be integrated into the EC network. A detailed analysis of the impact of the political developments in Eastern Europe is not within the scope of this Report. However, it is worth noting that the unification of the two systems will not be easy. DR has a very high share of both passenger and freight traffic and it is accepted that the total former East German transport infrastructure is in need of considerable investment. An early estimate by DB of DR's needs was for a programme of £38 bn of which 25 per cent would be for vehicles and 75 per cent for infrastructure. DB and DR have identified eight east-west links for priority improvements. Naturally, the move of the government functions from Bonn to Berlin will stimulate demand and a high speed electrified Hannover-Berlin link is expected to enter the construction stage in 1992. BR (GREAT BRITAIN) The British Railways Board was established in 1948 when it acquired the assets of the four major railway companies. The 1968 Transport Act established the concept of the commercial and social railways. Subsequently the commercial railway was defined as comprising the InterCity passenger services, freight operations and parcels services. The social railway was defined as consisting of regional (including rural) and commuter passenger services. British Rail was originally highly vertically and horizontally integrated. It owned hotels, ferry operations, docks and harbours, catering services, rolling stock construction and maintenance organisations and undertook a high proportion of civil engineering and signalling construction. Progressively it has divested itself of its non-railway activities and a much higher proportion of its services is now contracted out. Nevertheless, BR suffered as a result of the lack of clarity of objectives and in recent years has sought and obtained a contract from the government. From 1986 onwards the self-supporting businesses were required by the secretary of state for transport to provide a minimum 2.7 per cent per annum rate of return on their employed assets. BR, in common with other EC railways, receives an annual Public Service Obligation (PSO) grant through the implementation of a European Commission Directive. In BR's case the implementation was achieved by the 1974 Transport Act. The act required BR to retain the level and quality of services as existed in 1974 and concurrently to cover total costs out of the fare and grant revenue combined. Subsequently, the government set BR the objective of reducing the level of grant required. It had fallen to £574 mn by the end of the 1989/90 fiscal year. The government also set rising profitability

targets for the non-supported sectors (for example: £95 mn for InterCity by the end of 1992/93). Among the new objectives, the Network SouthEast sector, comprising mainly commuter services into London, was intended to be free of support by the end of 1992/93. The achievement of financial targets, however, is not wholly in BR's control since the traffic levels are influenced by the level of economic activity. It was apparent, for example, from UK government statements in early 1991, that there were doubts about the feasibility of Network SouthEast becoming financially independent. Moreover, estimates for the PSO grant for 1992/93 and 1993/94 have been revised upwards to £436 mn and £400 mn respectively. These represent increases of £90 mn and £55 mn. During 1990 BR went into a further stage of reorganisation. The business sectors, which previously internally "contracted" resources from the operating and infrastructure supply functions within BR, now between them assume ownership of these resources. Where there is common use of the facilities, the owning business sector contracts the use to the others. A large proportion of operations and traction and rolling stock will in future be dedicated. Substantial investment programmes (though considerably less than SNCF and DB) are being undertaken. The current Corporate Plan from 1989/90 to 1993/94 planned expenditure at the level of £4.9 bn with the major components being: Traction & rolling stock Infrastructure Terminals £ mn 2,576 1,494 836 BR is subject to approval of investment, some of which is funded internally and some by borrowing from the Treasury. There is an overall limit to funding, beyond the requirement that investment should achieve a return of 8 per cent, imposed by a specific External Financing Limit (EFL) which is one of the methods by which the government controls the funds available to the public sector. For the year 1989/90 the EFL was £635 mn. However, following financial results below expectation in 1990/91 the government was obliged to increase the level to £1,106 mn. The current government philosophy with regard to public transport is that the users and other beneficiaries from investment should pay for the benefits to the maximum achievable extent and that government grants or support should only be provided in respect of a proportion of the social benefits, for example reduced traffic congestion, where a levy cannot be extracted. BR operates within a highly defined set of financial and quality requirements. The quality requirements are defined by the secretary of state for transport and cover such issues as punctuality, timetable reliability, acceptable waiting times for ticket issues and for telephone enquiries. It is significant that the requirements do not include any specific volume or market share objectives other than general conditions that capacity should be kept in step with demand and that the board should provide a safe and efficient high quality railway which is responsive to the needs of its customers. British Rail is granted some flexibility in respect of pricing and InterCity, in particular, has segmented and increased prices significantly to optimise profitability. The next stages in sophistication are predicted to be in the form of yield management as practised by many airlines. However, that would involve a system of compulsory reservations which does not currently exist. BR has derived a significant proportion of its income from property sales, development and letting. The contribution in 1989/90 wcs £412 mn but the 1990/91 economic recession has affected this source of funds. Channel Tunnel services BR has established a new business sector — European Passenger Services — to be responsible for its interest in the rail services through the Channel Tunnel. BR is purchasing 14 of the Trans Manche Super Trains, SNCF 13 and SNCB three. The trains are specialised but have much in

common with the TGVs. Eurotunnel pic owns and will operate the track between the tunnel portals and the railways will purchase paths on the tracks. Currently, the plan is for up to 40 international passenger services and 27 freight trains daily. The technological complexities are substantial but so too are the marketing and management issues. The three railways have set up a Joint Business Managing Unit with the intention of creating practical recommendations covering at least the following issues: • level of service; • products; • prices; • catering; • terminal standards; • branding. The UK interests in Eurotunnel are drawn entirely from the private sector. For several years the UK Conservative government has sought to evolve an effective formula for the privatisation of British Rail. Despite the commitment to the principle, no scheme has yet found favour. How easily a private British railway could interact with two state owned European partners is a matter for speculation. FS (ITALY) FS was transformed from a government department into a state corporation in 1985. It remains within the ambit of the Ministry of Transport although it owns its assets and is required to be accountable for its financial results. For the maintenance or renewal of its assets it has access to borrowing or the issuing of State Guaranteed Bonds. Relationships with the government have been turbulent in the past five years and FS is heavily dependent on state support. In 1988 revenue make up was as follows: Passenger & freight Compensation & subsidies Other Total £ mn 1,431 5,526 884 7,841 State financial support is supposed to be confined to compensation for: • social service obligations; • contribution to infrastructure upkeep and renewals; and • grants for research and development. Major projects can be funded under special programmes. Investment between 1980 and 1989 totalled around £15 bn. Investment plans between 1990 and 1998 at a level of £38 bn have been approved by the government. The government exercises control over domestic tariffs although legislation in 1988 permitted FS to raise fares by 20 per cent per annum until parity was achieved with other West European railway prices. FS has three major difficulties in this context. One is the level of quality provided and the second is the degree to which reliability is affected by frequent industrial disputes. There is a third problem relating to the high level of discounting which results from a variety of social provisions or season tickets. Most of FS's passengers travel with some form of discount. (2)

10 Modernisation of some long distance passenger services has been implemented. By the summer of 1990 ETR 450 "tilt body" trains were running 13 services a day in each direction covering nine routes. Service quality has also been upgraded on regular InterCity services. FS features in 21 EuroCity services per day. For example, there is a Talgo Pendular overnight service between Madrid and Milan. There is no question that FS occupies a highly politicised environment. The issue of privatisation has been raised, the concept of a state provided infrastructure available for use by private companies has been considered and controversy has been generated by possible private sector involvement in joint ventures. RENFE (SPAIN) RENFE is a company incorporated under Spanish public law as a commercial company to which the operation of all the normal gauge railway network is entrusted. It has a status independent of the state and the power to develop its own objectives. The current objectives are embodied in a plan approved by Spain's Council of Ministers and are to be implemented under a four year Contract Programme (1988-91). The essence of the Contract Programme is that RENFE commits itself to achieving specified results and the state assumes obligations with respect to the financing of the operation and investment. The commitments made by RENFE under the contract include the rationalisation and improvement of management, a financial reorganisation and a reduction in the annual deficit. By 1989 the annual deficit had fallen from the 1984 level of £343 mn to £53 mn. A reduction in the accumulated deficit from £1.25 bn to £1.1 bn was also achieved. Following its entry into the EC, Spain acquired the Public Service Obligation requirement. In 1988 the payment was £588 mn. It was directed to suburban, regional and branch line passenger services. Additionally, under further EC provisions, RENFE qualified for financial support during the period of reorganisation and asset renewal. This embraces the funding of long-term deficits and working capital, and the cost of raising investment capital. In 1988 the global volume of subsidy was £336 mn. The 1988 contract made provision for a four year investment programme of £3.26 bn of which £2.1 bn would be the responsibility of RENFL and £1.2 bn would be provided by the Ministry of Transport, Tourism and Communications. The contract also set out traffic volume related targets. New simplified pricing policies were required with some emphasis on achieving higher returns from the improved InterCity services. Management information and a new management structure based on business accountability was introduced. The RENFE gauge of 1,668 mm is not compatible with that of the majority of the EC railways. (Some international Talgo services are operated by trains that are able to convert to 1,435 mm.) Decisions to construct a completely new high speed 1,435 mm gauge route from Madrid to Seville and the possibility of a similar new line from Madrid to Barcelona and on to the French border have raised considerable anxieties that other planned investments may be displaced by the cost of these schemes. As with many other European rail networks, RENFE has applied modern technology, utilising the tilting Talgo trains on a significant scale. Among its information technology developments are radio communication systems between trains and traffic control points, and the development of a sophisticated reservations system with the facility for interconnection between the Iberia and RENFE networks. RENFE reduced its staff from 82,000 in 1970 to 50,000 by 1988.

11 SBB (SWITZERLAND) Swiss Federal Railways has managerial freedom over its InterCity passenger and freight operations. It is the second largest property owner in Switzerland. The state has assumed financial but not managerial responsibility for infrastructure. On its commercial operations, SBB pays a contribution towards the use of infrastructure. For the socially supported services, the government has the right to specify levels of service and it funds the unrecovered costs. SBB retains control of commercial action, operations and rolling stock of these services. SBB yielded operating surpluses from 1985 to 1989. In 1989 total revenue was £2.02 bn, of which the federal compensation was £255 mn. Passenger revenue and volumes have grown over the period 1985-89. SBB investment plans for passenger services incorporated in the "Bahn 2000" project were finally approved by a national referendum in December 1987. Total planned expenditure is approximately £2.2 bn. The principle of "Bahn 2000" is the maximisation of the ease and convenience of using the rail passenger network (which is unusually accessible to the majority of Swiss citizens — 60 per cent of all households are within 1 km of a railway station). A pattern of connecting services is based upon main nodal cities. The prevailing principle is that the nodal city should be served every hour and that the journey times between nodes should be just under one hour. The concept relates to speed only within the need that "travel time should be as fast as is necessary" to provide an attraction to the market and to make the interconnections possible. Some 130 km of new track are being constructed which should be suitable for 200 km/h operation. However, overall speeds will be improved significantly between many city pairs when the plan has been implemented. SBB reduced its staff from just under 41,000 in 1975 to just under 37,400 in 1989. SBB has developed strong marketing links with Swissair and the InterCity services are routed to the main airports at Zürich and Geneva. It is also collaborating with OBB and DB in the launch of overnight hotel trains in 1994 with new rolling stock. In the interim two Talgo train sets are operating the Basle-Vienna overnight service and French TGV services also run to Geneva. NS (NETHERLANDS) NS is a limited company wholly owned by the state. State support is substantial. Out of the total 1988 revenue of £988 mn the state support element was £427 mn. Most of this relates to the infrastructure subsidy (£374 mn in 1989). In 1988 NS published a Rail 21 programme setting out rail capacity expansion. The plan was accepted and nearly £3 bn is incorporated into the plans of the Ministry of Transport and Public Works. Plan 21 includes the provision of three new high speed lines which, inter alia, will be used by, international services into Germany, into France and via Belgium through the Channel Tunnel. The plan also embraces an expansion of capacity to ease ten bottlenecks and to accommodate three levels of passenger services. The premier level embraces InterCity and EuroCity trains running at up to 200 km/h. The next level is called Express Inter-Regional, embracing 65 Netherlands cities and towns. Half hour interval services are envisaged at speeds of 140-160 km/h. The third tier, Aggio-Regio, would operate through the main centres connecting suburban areas.

12 NS has growing passenger volumes; 1989 showed an increase of 5 per cent on 1988. Fares are falling, in real terms at least, partly as a result of government policies. NS has an agreement with the government which provides support in return for service quality and provision guarantees. Although fares are standardised at present, NS anticipates charging higher fares for its new higher quality passenger products. NS restructured its management in 1990. The chairman has a functional directorate of five: • commercial; • development; • production; • personnel; • financial. At the next level are four product marketing departments: • international passenger services; • InterCity passenger services; • local passenger services; • freight, mail and parcels. OTHER EUROPEAN RAILWAYS The diversity exhibited in the state management, internal organisation, planning and funding of investment in the main railways of Western Europe so far described is reflected within the remaining eight in the scope of this study. All have aspirations for higher speed long distance passenger services, though this is somewhat muted in the case of VR (Finland). All, too, have investment plans — entitled in the case of ÖBB (Austria) "Neue Bahn", SNCB (Belgium) "Star 21", DSB (Denmark) "Plan 2000" and NSB (Norway) "Tog 2004". In all cases governments have sought to identify or specify services which should be commercially self-supporting. They have also designated those of a social character for which the state will provide funding. With the support provided by the state, the railways are required either to eliminate their operating deficits (ÖBB, DSB, VR, NSB and SJ) or to contain them. ÖBB has a contract and SNCB is expecting to move towards a contractual relationship. The major differences between the railways lie in the treatment of infrastructure. In Belgium and Norway the state assumes responsibility for infrastructure costs and investment. In Austria and Finland, as in Switzerland, infrastructure provision is regarded as a state responsibility and, in respect of the railway's commercial services, the operator is charged for the use of it. However, in all cases the national railways actually manage the infrastructure. The charges levied reflect attempts to create some equivalence with the infrastructure costs borne by the operators of other modes of transport. In Sweden a major separation has occurred between infrastructure provision and operation. In July 1988 the government set up a new organisation for the national infrastructure maintenance and investment responsibilities. SJ is now purely an operator of railway services. It has a core of commercial services and social and regional services operated under contracts to regional authorities. Significantly, SJ has no remaining monopoly rights to the operation of railway passenger services. The Swedish government is adopting social cost benefit analysis as a means of allocating resources to all forms of transport investment, and reflecting continuing government infrastructure subsidies. * * * **

The amended Treaty contains a chapter entitled "Environment" (Articles 130 R, S, and T) which sets out the objectives of Community environmental policy and the specific powers for the passing of an environmental legislation. Article 130 of the amended Treaty states that the objectives of Community environmental policy are to preserve, protect and improve the environment, to contribute towards protecting human health and to ensure a prudent and rational utilisation of natural resources. The importance of preventive action is emphasised as a means of achieving these objectives. — and procedures — The procedure for the adoption of environmental legislation is given in Article 130S. Most legislation adopted under this Article requires a unanimous vote of the Council but, if so agreed, subsidiary measures may be adopted by qualified majority. Two important points should be noted: • under Article 130T a state may maintain or adopt more stringent environmental standards than those set by a Directive provided these do not interfere with the harmonisation of trade; and • arguably, the most significant Treaty amendment under Article 130 is the provision in Article 130R that "environmental protection requirements shall be a component of the Community's other policies". The new provisions relating to environmental legislation under the amended Treaty apply alongside the general powers given in Articles 235 and 100 (both of which require unanimous voting). Article 235 allows the Community to take appropriate measures in the absence of specific powers if such action is necessary to attain one of the objectives of the Community. Article 100 concerns the harmonisation of legislation throughout the Community so as to ensure fair competition among member states.

14 — while linking environmental legislation to the establishment of the internal market The statement of principle in Article 130 that the requirements of environment policy shall constitute a component part of other Community policies, is taken further in the new Article 100A, which provides for voting by qualified majority on legislation regulating the establishment and functioning of the internal market. It provides that in proposing "harmonising legislation aimed at the achievement of the internal market, the Commission must take a high level of environmental protection as a base. One of the purposes of Article 100A was to respond to "the need to combine, by way of actions which effectively protect the environment, two of the main Treaty objectives, ie the achievement of the internal market and the development of a high level of environmental standards within the Community" — Officialjournal of the European Communities No C328/7. It also recognises that environmental measures taken by member states acting independently may distort competition or create new intra-Community trade barriers and thus hinder the achievement of the internal market. Article 100A again permits member states to adopt stricter standards if they consider it necessary for the protection of their own environment. CONCLUSIONS Ensuring the effective implementation of EC environmental directives is crucial if the growing volume of legislation is to result in any real improvement in the quality of the environment. The Commission recognises this and has made the monitoring of implementation one of its priorities. The Commission has also shown a readiness to take enforcement action both as a result of its own investigations and in response to complaints received from pressure groups and the public. Growing public awareness of environmental issues is shown by the increase in the number of complaints about environmental matters sent to the Commission. The Seventh Annual Report to the European Parliament on European Commission Monitoring of the Application of Community Law in 1989 noted that in that year the Commission received more than 465 complaints from individuals and pressure groups concerning the application of EC legislation in the environmental sector, compared with 190 complaints in the environmental sector sent to the Commission in 1988, and fewer than 11 submissions in 1985. These figures indicate increasing public concern about environmental issues generally and about the lack of effective implementation of environmental measures in the member states. Effective implementation is more likely to be achieved where the public are kept well informed about their country's performance in the environmental field. In France, for example, the results of the monitoring of bathing water are easily accessible to holiday makers. So the authorities in each locality have a vested interest in ensuring that those results are satisfactory in order to prevent damage to their local tourist industry. This is not the case in many other countries. At the national level, governments can no longer afford to be complacent about the environment. A willingness on the part of national governments to admit the existence of environmental problems and to commit financial and human resources to resolving those problems is the first step to a cleaner and safer Europe. * * * **

In General It is generally believed by tax professionals, that the taxation of international partnerships may be a trap for the unwary, a playing field for tax advisors and an area of concern for tax authorities. While partnerships may provide for more flexibility than corporations in structuring international business relationships because of the statutory provisions governing the operation of corporations, the uncertainty as to the taxation of income of an international partnership is a major factor for business venturers to elect the corporate form for their business relationship. One of the major uncertainties in the taxation of a resident entrepreneur that participates in a foreign partnership is the classification of such foreign partnership for domestic tax purposes. Should such partnership be classified as transparent for tax purposes or should in instead be classified as a foreign corporation? This issue will be examined for three different countries: the United States, Germany and the Ne­ therlands. The emphasis will be on the general and limited partnership as they are known in the United States, Germany and the Netherlands.

24 Despite different legal definitions of the relationship that constitutes a partnership, three common characteristics can be found in all three countries. A partnership can be defined as: a contractual relationship between persons; aimed at the sharing of benefits; that arise from the joint contribution of resources. For example, in the United States, the Uniform Partnership Act? defines the general partnership as: 3 "... an association of two or more persons to carry on as co-owners a business for profit." In the Netherlands, the civil law partnerstup (maatschap) is defined as: 4 "... a contract by which two or more persons commit themselves to jointly contribute something, in order to share the benefits thereof. " The general partnership is defined as: 5 "... a civil law partnership for the purpose of carrying on a business under a common name. " In Germany, the definitions are similar in scope to those in the Netherlands. Article 707 of the Civil Code (Bürgerliches Gesetzbuch) defines the civil law partnership (Gesellschaft Bürgerlichen Rechts) as follows: "Through the partnership contract, the partners commit themselves mutually to promote a common objective in a commonly agreed upon way, especially to contribute the agreed upon resources. " The German general partnership is defined in the Commercial Code (Handelsgesetzbuch) as: 6 "A civil law partnership of which the purpose is to conduct a trade or business under a common firm ...." One therefore can conclude that the general partnership in all three countries is a partnership for the purpose of carrying on a business. Also common in all three countries is the limited partnership. In a limited partnership, the limited partners are not liable for the obligations of the limited partnership. The liability of a limited partner is limited the contribution to the capital of the partnership, unless the limited partner takes part in the management of the limited partnerships' business. A partnership is created intuitu personae, meaning that the personal factor in the relationship between the partners is important. Since, generally, the partners of a (general) partnership all are principals and agents for each other, it is clear that the personal relationships between the partners are important. Consequently, as a general rule, no partner is free to substitute another person for him as a partner in the partnership. To distinguish a partnership from other contractual arrangements, the criterion of affectio societatis is sometimes used. 7 This criterion designates the partnership as an agreement to jointly conduct an activity in cooperation with and on an equal basis by all partners. The criterion is closely related to the criterion of intuitu personea. It is based on the notion of joint control by all partners over the business of the partnership. The criterion may be used to distinguish a partnership from contracts such as loan agreements, lease contracts or employment contracts.

25 From a civil law point of view, it can be said that a partnership has a dual nature. On the one hand, a partnership functions as an entity in economic life by doing business in its own name, keeping books and records, earning profits and by suing and being sued. The functioning of the partnership as an entity also follows from the ability of the partnership to enter into transactions with a partner in a capacity of one who is not a partner. 1 Finally, creditors of the partnership have priority over creditors of the partners in executing on partnership property.' On the other hand, the partnership is an aggregation of persons, the partners. A partnership lacks legal personality, so that while property may be held in the name of the partnership, it is held by the joint partners as co- owners. 10 Furthermore, partners in a partnership are personally liable for the partnership's debts and the partnership will generally be dissolved upon the bankruptcy or death of a partner. This article will focus on the basic issue in the taxation of income from a foreign partnership namely the methods applied when classifying a foreign entity as a fiscally transparent partnership or, instead, as a taxable corporation. The article is structured as a comparative law analysis focusing on the tax laws in the United States, Germany and the Netherlands. Π. Methods of classification 1. The basic similarity in the classification rules as applied in the United States, Germany and the Netherlands, is that they all focus on the legal relationships between the entity and the participators as determined under (foreign) civil law. The foreign tax treatment of the entity is not relevant in classifying the foreign entity for domestic tax purposes. 2. The analysis shows that the United States has developed the most detailed rules for classification of foreign entities for tax purposes. The regulations on classification, combined with Rev. Ruling 88-8 according to which all foreign entities are considered as unincorporated entities, provide certainty as to the basic questions that may arise when classifying a foreign entity. Furthermore, the Internal Revenue Code is consistent in that the same classification rules apply for domestic taxpayers participating in foreign entities and foreign entities receiving domestic source income. In addition, the Internal Revenue Code is consistent in that the same classification rules apply in classifying domestic and foreign organizations, a principle that has been confirmed in Rev. Ruling 73-254. The consistency in the classification rules is, however, broken by Rev. Ruling 88-8 and Rev. Ruling 77-214. The holding of Rev. Ruling 88-8

26 can be concurred with, since the mere designation of a foreign entity as a body corporate under the laws under which it is organized does not reveal much about the true nature of the entity. Rev. Ruling 77-214 introduced the "single economic interest theory" by holding that a foreign entity that is (indirectly) wholly-owned by a United States corporation, has freely transferable interests and continuity of life, since there are no separate interests that may compel dissolution of the entity or may vote against transfers of interests. The single economic interest theory must be rejected on systematic grounds, since it produces unnecessary inconsistencies in the classification of foreign and domestic entities and, furthermore, creates uncertainties, since, in its ultimate reasoning the single economic interest theory implies that United States multi nationals could never operate abroad through a wholly-owned foreign subsidiary classified as a corporation, because such an entity lacks the corporate characteristic of associates. Finally, the single economic interest theory creates the tendency to somewhat artificially introduce true outside parties holding a 5 percent interest in the foreign entity. 3. In Germany, the rules for classifying foreign entities have been set by case law beginning in 1930. The German rule is that a foreign entity is classified on the basis of the domestic entity that it most resembles from a legal and econo mic viewpoint. While this theory results in consistency in classifying domestic and foreign entities, it may be difficult to apply in practice and therefore it may result in more uncertainty as to the classification of certain foreign entities. 4. In the Netherlands, no explicit rules for classifying foreign entities have been set in tax legislation or regulations, except for the so-called foreign open in-vestment fund. From case law and the general system of the Income Tax Act and the Corporate Tax Act, a set of classification rules can, however, be developed. On the basis of these classification rules, two factors determine the classification of a foreign entity. The first question is whether the foreign entity is a body corporate in the sense that the entity is the owner of assets and liabilities in its own name and for its own account, separate from the rights and obligations of the participators. The second factor is the transferability of interests in the foreign entity. Both factors focus on the internal legal relation ships between the entity and the participators. It was argued that limited liability of the entity is not a factor in classifying it for tax purposes. If, under foreign civil law, the entity may be the owner of assets and liabilities in its own name and for its own account, the entity will be classified as a foreign corporation. If the entity is not the owner of assets and liabilities in its own name and for its own account, the classification of the entity depends on its activities. If the entity is carrying on a trade or business, it may be classified as an open limited partnership or as a partnership with a capital divided into shares, if the (limited) partners' interests are freely transferable. Interests are freely transferable if participators may be substituted or admitted without the consent of all other participators. If interests are not freely transferable, the entity is classified as a fiscally transparent partnership. This set of classification rules creates, consistency between classification of en tities for income as well as corporate tax purposes, as well as between domestic and foreign entities. * * ¥ ¥ ¥

29 (D ©Λ* REVUEDÉcoNOMiEFiNANCiÈRE η" 18 ­ Automne 1991 ^ 0/ La dette publique dans les pays de l'OCDE Jean-Claude Chouraqui ocoe ^ pp, l VS—Zij Définitions Trois problèmes de définition se posent lorsqu'on traite de la dette publique. Faut­il considérer la dette brute ou la dette nette ? Est­il préférable de prendre en compte la dette de l'Etat, celle des Administrations publiques ou celle du secteur public dans son ensemble (entreprises publiques compri­ ses) ? Enfin, y a­t­il lieu de distinguer entre dette intérieure et dette extérieure ? 1) Lorsqu'on parle de la dette publique, il s'agit généralement de la dette brute (c'est­à­dire les engagements financiers totaux de l'Etat), étant donné que les chiffres correspondants sont plus facilement disponibles, et donc plus largement diffusés, et qu'il existe un lien direct entre la dette brute et le montant des versements d'intérêts au titre du service de la dette (facteur qui entre pour une large part dans les inquiétudes suscitées par l'évolution de la dette). La dette nette (c'est­à­dire les engagements financiers bruts diminués des actifs financiers) reflète en revanche plus précisément le volume total des déficits budgétaires accumulés dans le passé, lequel représente les emprunts nets contractés par les Administrations publiques au cours du temps. La meilleure façon d'apprécier la différence entre les deux concepts est d'examiner la nature des actifs financiers du secteur public, puisque ce sont eux qui constituent l'écart entre la dette brute et la dette nette. Ces actifs sont de deux ordres : les créances détenues par l'Etat en tant qu'intermédiaire financier, et les ressources de la Sécurité Sociale constituées en prévision d'obligations futures. En tant qu'intermédiaire financier, l'Etat emprunte des fonds (qui gonflent sa dette financière brute) afin de financer des prêts aux particuliers (prêts hypothécaires notamment) et à diverses institutions (prêts d'équipe­ ment pour le développement régional par exemple). Les créances ainsi acquises rapportent normalement à l'Etat des intérêts et devraient donc légitimement représenter une contrepartie de sa dette brute. Il est cependant deux problèmes liés à ces actifs financiers qui, dans certains pays et dans des proportions variables, donnent à penser qu'il ne convient peut­être pas de les déduire de la dette brute. Premièrement, dans certains cas, les intérêts versés à l'Etat par les particuliers ou les organismes emprunteurs ne permettent pas à celui­ci de couvrir ses coûts financiers. Deuxièmement, si la qualité.des actifs financiers détenus par l'Etat est sujette à caution, la valeur réelle de ces actifs peut être moindre que leur valeur comptable. Ce peut être le cas notamment des prêts à des sociétés privées insolvables ou à certaines entreprises publiques. L'autre catégorie importante d'actifs financiers détenus par l'Etat est liée aux ressources de la Sécurité Sociale. Dans plusieurs pays, une large fraction de ces ressources est associée au financement des régimes de retraites, lesquels impliquent pour l'Etat de lourdes obligations dans l'avenir. La dette brute ne tient généralement pas compte de la Sécurité Sociale, ce qui constitue une importante lacune du fait des conséquences du vieillissement de la population. Les chiffres de la dette nette risquent aussi d'induire en erreur parce qu'ils ne prennent en considération que Γ« actif » du bilan de la Sécurité Sociale. Dans certains pays, notamment le Japon, ces chiffres ne sont

30 pas en fait jugés significatifs par les pouvoirs publics dans la mesure où ces derniers prévoient que l'évolution démographique réduira sensiblement les ressources de la Sécurité Sociale dans le futur. En résumé, les liens entre la dette nette et les déficits budgétaires font qu'il est préférable d'utiliser la dette nette pour analyser l'évolution de l'endettement du secteur public. Etant donné cependant les problèmes liés à la qualité des actifs financiers, l'existence d'engagements implicites au titre des retraites et l'importance que revêt le service de la dette, il importe de tenir compte également de la dette brute. 2) La deuxième grande question que soulève la définition de la dette publique concerne le type d'Administration considéré. Dans certains pays, on se préoccupe essentiellement de la dette de l'Etat (ou Administration centrale), alors que dans d'autres on s'inquiète surtout des engagements de l'ensemble des Administrations publiques (Etat, collectivités locales et Sécurité Sociale) ou du secteur public dans sa totalité (c'est-à-dire y compris les entreprises publiques). La définition la plus étroite (dette de l'Etat) pourrait se justifier dans la mesure où l'on dispose de données plus abondantes pour cette catégorie de dette et du fait que celle-ci est plus sujette à « monétisation » (les Banques centrales n'achetant ou n'escomptant généralement pas de titres émis par les collectivités locales). Un certain nombre de difficultés surgissent cependant lorsqu'on veut comparer les chiffres de la dette de l'Etat de divers pays, étant donné notamment que certains d'entre eux ont une structure fédérale et d'autres pas. A l'inverse, la définition la plus large (dette du secteur public) peut se justifier si l'on se place dans une optique de compte de patrimoine (voir ci-après). De fait, l'Etat détient généralement des actions d'entreprises publiques, actions qui ne sont pas comptabilisées parmi ses actifs financiers (du moins à leur valeur réelle). Les ventes de ces actions peuvent modifier la dette nette et la dette brute de l'Etat, mais pas nécessairement son patrimoine global, d'où l'utilité d'une mesure de la dette du secteur public dans son ensemble. Toutefois, une telle évaluation soulève d'importants problèmes de données et de définition au plan international et, en règle générale, l'activité des entreprises publiques est assez proche de celle des entreprises privées. Aussi, tout bien considéré, l'utilisation du concept intermédiaire (dette des Administrations publiques) est-elle la plus appro priée, vu qu'elle permet une comparabilité raisonnable entre les pays et qu'elle est compatible avec les définitions de la comptabilité nationale. Au demeurant, dans beaucoup de pays, l'évolution de la dette de l'Etat et celle des Administrations publiques ont été très voisines ces dernières années. 3) Enfin, une distinction doit être faite au sujet de la dette publique de certains pays qui ont recours à un financement extérieur : quel est le montant de la dette détenue par des non-résidents et quel est le montant libellé en devises ? Les emprunts extérieurs fournissent des ressources supplémentaires permettant aux pays considérés d'investir plus qu'ils n'épargnent, à des taux d'intérêt plus faibles que ce ne serait le cas autrement. En revanche, les intérêts versés sur la dette détenue par des non-résidents ne constituent pas un transfert interne (ils sont comptabilisés dans la balance des paiements courants et réduisent ainsi le PNB et le revenu national), de sorte que la capacité de service de la dette revêt une importance encore plus grande qu'à l'ordinaire. De plus, le recours au financement extérieur peut parfois affecter la compétitivité de l'économie, notamment si les entrées de capitaux se traduisent par une appréciation du taux de change. Toutefois, pour un volume donné de la dette extérieure totale, il importe peu (sur le plan économique) que ce soit l'Etat ou le secteur privé qui emprunte à l'étranger.

36 [pip-M- lil) CONCLUSION Le survol européen que nous venons d'effectuer nous conforte dans l'intérêt que nous avions trouvé à développer l'éveil artistique chez l'enfant dès son plus jeune âge. Si les Finlandais considèrent que les arts encouragent l'expression et le jugement esthétique et créatif de l'enfant lui permettant « un développement harmonieux de sa personnalité », les Britanniques vont sans doute plus loin en affirmant qu'« ils jouent un rôle unique et constituent une composante essentielle de la préparation à la vie adulte ». Il existe pourtant entre tous les pays des différences sémantiques sur le sens donné aux termes « art » ou « artistique », certains privilégient la notion « d'essence », d'autres celle de « valeur » d'autres encore mêlent subtilement les deux. Le cas limite est présenté par la Norvège qui ne possède pas dans sa langue de vocable pour désigner l'art qu'il définit cependant comme étant « le fruit de la culture passée offrant en même temps des qualités liées au présent ». Il est pour ce pays l'un des principaux moyens de communication dont dispose l'homme. Le niveau de développement du travail féminin, tout comme l'amplitude des horaires de travail des deux parents ont également une influence importante sur l'éveil artistique apporté par la famille aux enfants. Car il faut le repéter c'est d'abord dans son foyer que l'enfant reçoit sa première sensibilisation à la musique, à la peinture ou à n'importe quel art. Par ailleurs la présence des mères sur le marché de l'emploi peut être aussi perçue comme une meilleure ouverture sur le monde extérieur et une plus grande réceptivité au monde des arts. Tous nos voisins, ceux du Nord de l'Europe qui ont engagé une réflexion et une politique sur ce thème depuis longtemps comme ceux du sud pour lesquels cette préoccupation est plus récente, ont inscrit dans leurs programmes scolaires une ou plusieurs disciplines artistiques, le plus souvent deux, de manière obligatoire. La préscolarisation (1) lorsqu'elle existe fait une très large part à cet éveil à travers les activités ludiques proposées aux jeunes enfants, histoires, rondes, comptines, chansons, dessin, peinture ou modelage nourrissent l'imaginaire et développent la créativité de tous les petits européens. C'est après ces années de libre expression avec le début de la scolarité obligatoire que les différences apparaissent. Pour être volontairement schématique, nous pourrions distinguer deux types de systèmes éducatifs, ceux qui s'appuient sur des programmes dont l'acquisition est périodiquement contrôlée et sanctionnée, et ceux qui, à partir d'objectifs finaux, s'adaptent aux possibilités d'acquisition de chaque enfant. Les rythmes scolaires en vigueur reflètent ces grandes options de même que la place accordée aux arts dans les enseignements. D'une manière générale les pays de l'Europe du nord respectent les rythmes de l'enfant qui dispose ainsi chaque jour de larges plages horaires pour les activités de son choix. Plus tard à l'école on constate que les disciplines artistiques figurent dans tous les programmes en Europe. Sous des vocables différents se cachent des réalités différentes : arts plastiques ou visuels, expression plastique, travail manuel ; théâtre ou expression dramatique ; danse ou expression corporelle... Deux groupes de disciplines sont privilégiés dans l'ensemble des pays, le groupe des arts plastiques et celui de la musique. Tous deux sont placés dans cet ordre sauf en l'Irlande où ce palmarès est inversé. Il faut reconnaître que la tradition musicale est très forte dans ce pays. Le groupe des arts plastiques est sans doute celui qui recouvre le plus de réalités différentes: se côtoient l'histoire de la peinture et sa pratique sous des formes académiques ou créatrices, le dessin, le design, la sculpture, le modelage mais aussi la réalisation de travaux tridimensionnels voire la création d'objets usuels en bois, métal, pierre ou tissu. Les pays du nord sont ceux qui vont le plus loin dans cette discipline qui bénéficie d'horaires étendus grâce aux séances de travaux manuels. C'est sans doute encore une fois la Norvège qui se distingue dans ce groupe par son « vorming ». Ce terme regroupe le dessin, les travaux manuels des garçons et ceux des filles. Ce concept qui réunit les arts et les techniques introduit également une notion nouvelle celle de l'environnement. (1) C'est au Danemark en Italie et en France que les crèches et les écoles maternelles sont le plus développées, en revanche en Grande-Bretagne, au Luxembourg, aux Pays-Bas et en Irlande moins de S % des enfants de moins de 4 ans sont accueillis dans de tels services c'est l'environnement familial qui assure la garde des jeunes enfants.

37 Parmi les objectifs (1) fixés au «vorming» figure en effet la nécessité d'apprendre aux enfants à partager la responsabilité de leur environnement. Cette préoccupation est partagée par de nombreux pays du nord de l'Europe. Cette approche nous paraît particulièrement intéressante en ce qu'elle ne fait pas de discrimination elitiste entre Beaux-arts, arts appliqués et artisanat. Elle permet une bonne diffusion de la préoccupation artistique dans tout acte de création. Il est regrettable que notre pays n'ait pas choisi cette voie en particulier dans les établissements d'enseignement technique ou paradoxalement cet enseignement nous a semblé moins présent : dans les lycées techniques il n'y a plus d'éducation musicale mais une seule heure hebdomadaire consacrée aux arts plastiques ou appliqués. C'est pourtant là que l'effort devrait le plus se développer. En effet, les enfants qui fréquentent ces établissements sont souvent issus de milieux défavorisés pour lesquels l'éveil artistique n'est pas toujours une préoccupation majeure. 13,8 % d'entre eux sortent chaque année du système scolaire sans diplôme ni qualification professionnelle leur permettant d'accéder à un emploi. On sait que la créativité est nécessaire dans l'exercice de tout travail manuel. Les artisans regrettent de ne pas trouver chez leurs apprentis ou leurs jeunes ouvriers ces qualités inventives et esthétiques. Si les travaux manuels d'antan, cantonnés dans la vannerie, le cartonnage, ne peuvent être regrettés, en revanche le travail des formes, des volumes et des couleurs dans le bois, la pierre, le métal, le tissu, l'argile, le plâtre ou tout autre matériau devrait être encouragé et développé mais dans une visée utilitaire comme dans les arts appliqués ou l'artisanat. Le futur technicien comme le futur artisan doivent avoir eu la possibilité d'exercer leurs potentialités créatrices si l'on veut qu'ils deviennent de bons professionnels. C'est peut-être par l'éveil artistique que passe la revalorisation de certains métiers manuels. Les pays du nord de l'Europe ont compris depuis longtemps et rencontrent de bons succès en matière d'esthétique industrielle ou de design; chacun connaît la beauté des formes des mobiliers danois ou de certains objets suédois. Concernant l'éducation musicale là aussi de grandes disparités existent entre les pays comme la France, qui se limitent le plus souvent à la théorie, c'est-à-dire à l'histoire de la musique et au solfège, et ceux qui privilégient la pratique vocale ou instrumentale. Il faut remarquer que le choix est souvent orienté par des considérations d'ordre économique, la pratique exigeant à la fois des salles insonorisées et des instruments souvent très coûteux. Pourtant, sans pratique ni même audition de musique qui nécessitent des lieux spécifiques, il est difficile de transmettre un quelconque amour de la musique. Savoir qui est Mozart et quelles sont ses œuvres c'est bien, mais l'avoir écouté c'est mieux. C'est même la seule façon d'avoir encore envie de l'écouter ou d'en jouer... Le chant choral qui connaît depuis quelques années un renouveau dans notre pays est très pratiqué notamment dans les pays du Nord et de l'Est. Les concerts et récitals organisés dans les établissements scolaires permettent les rencontres entre enfants d'une même région, d'un même pays ou d'autres pays. La plupart des pays reconnaissent aussi l'importance du rôle de la danse et du théâtre. Ces deux disciplines ont leur place à l'école et au collège, la première dans le cadre de l'éducation physique, la seconde à l'occasion de l'apprentissage de la langue maternelle, parfois des langues étrangères. En France, danse et éducation physique qui sont perçues commme deux disciplines différentes par la forme et les objectifs poursuivis, ne font pas bon ménage même si parfois certains professeurs de gymnastique s'aident de la musique pour rythmer leurs mouvements. La danse est pratiquement absente de l'école sauf à l'occasion de quelques rares ateliers de pratique artistique. La danse est pourtant un art que les enfants pratiquent spontanément. L'art dramatique est plus conçu comme un outil d'apprentissage que comme un art à part entière dans la plupart des pays. En France, il réalise à travers les ateliers de pratique artistique un excellent score puisqu'il arrive en deuxième position dans le choix des collégiens. C'est aussi une façon d'approfondir les techniques d'expression et d'élocution des élèves. Seule la R.F.A. accorde à cet art son véritable statut dans certains Länder. (1) Pour éveiller une participation active des élèves par la création, il est nécessaire : — procurer l'expérience de l'utilisation et de l'interprétation correcte de la peinture, de la sculpture en tant que moyens d'expression individuels et sociaux : — stiumuler les perceptions et l'imagination en alliant idée et pratique ; — développer la perception esthétique grâce au travail des matériaux ; — aider les élèves à considérer leur travail comme s'incrivanl dans le cadre d'une expression culturelle et á développer un sens critique à l'égard des Beaux-Arts et leur apprendre ainsi à partager la responsabilité de leur environnement.

38 Enfin, mis à part la Grande-Bretagne, l'Irlande et les Pays-Bas, peu de pays accordent une grande importance à l'écriture et à la littérature, en dehors du cadre de l'apprentissage de la langue maternelle. La diversification des disciplines telle qu'elle est introduite en France par les ateliers de pratique artistique ou les projets d'action éducative est peu répandue. Nous sommes pratiquement les seuls en Europe à développer la photographie, et progressivement le cinéma ou la vidéo. En revanche pratiquement dans tous les pays une importance croissante est apportée à l'environnement. Il s'agit d'une véritable dimension transversale qui marque cet intérêt pour la nature et la nécessité de la préserver â travers les arts. On peut regretter que la France n'ait pas cette préoccupation qui apparaît cependant dans les ateliers et classes culturelles en architecture et classes de patrimoine. La dimension transversale n'est pas évidente chez nous. Le manque d'exigence de qualité esthétique de nos concitoyens pour leur environnement bâti et non bâti en serait-il la conséquence ? Pour ne pas clore cette tentative de comparaison sur une note aussi pessimiste, il faut reconnaître qu'à travers les informations que nous avons pu recueillir, il est apparu une certaine unanimité dans tous les pays étudiés, pour déplorer à l'école comme dans les mentalités en générai, un certain désintérêt sinon une dévalorisation pour les disciplines artistiques. Ceci se traduit par: — des moyens financiers et techniques insuffisants, — des horaires trop réduits, — des personnels peu formés (monovalents, bivalents ou même plurivalents ces maîtres peuvent n'avoir à enseigner qu'une discipline artistique ou deux, voire plusieurs, mais aussi devoir compléter leur horaire par des matières non artistiques), — des parents peu soucieux d'exiger pour les disciplines artistiques la même rigueur que pour les autres matières. Toutefois, même si le partenariat sous sa forme institutionnalisée reste originale à la France, il faut admettre que la nécessité d'une certaine collaboration entre enseignants et artistes. État et collectivités locales, associations, entreprises et parents est reconnue indispensable dans l'ensemble des pays. Pour les activités périscolaires et à un moindre degré à l'école primaire, c'est le niveau local qui contribue le plus financièrement à l'éveil artistique des jeunes. Dans tous les pays le rôle des associations est très actif. * * * **

Introduction The growing inefficiency of the postal service, ever more obvious with the progress of modern society, the increase in competition from new services outside the state monopoly but which substitute postal services (fax, telematic post) and the success of private couriers, make it necessary for us to open a debate on the present organization of postal companies in all industrialized countries. The purpose of this paper is to examine the motivation for a state monopoly of the postal services. In so doing, two frequently heard generalisations must be avoided. One is to accept in an uncritical way the theory that private management is better anyway ­ and this is a risk we find in many Anglo­saxon studies in support of a complete privatisation of all units of public services. The other, which is normally found in the arguments of the postal companies, is to use any argument whatever from economic theory to create a case, however relevant or not it may be, for justifying the upholding of the state monopoly. A study that examines the arguments in favor of one or the other is made necessary by the very nature of the problem because it is not difficult to appreciate that valid reasons can be given in support of each side. The difficult thing to do, which we attempt in this paper, is to make an assessment of the relative importance of each so as to be able, even at a very general level, to give some indication of the directions a change should take in order to better the service. The paper is organized as follows: in the next chapter we briefly illustrate the main problems of the postal services and specifically give some indications of their quality. In chapter three we examine the justification put forward by companies in support of state monopoly. The analysis of these justifications is done in chapter 4 where specifically we examine the theses in favour of a natural monopoly. The thesis, instead, that makes the state monopoly depend on the obligation to apply uniform prices throughout the country is examined in chapters 4.2 and 4.3. Chapter 5 suggests an alternative interpretation both for the natural monopoly and for the problem of uniform costs in order to set out the reasoning for the creation of and maintenance of the state monopoly. 40 8. Concluding remarks Our examination of the reasons underpinning state monopoly has demonstrated that the theory of natural monopoly is weak. Specifically, if the Post Offices can be compared to a single-product enterprise, then even if we admit that this would be a natural monopoly, it in no way demands that a legal monopoly be established. The technology in itself is enough to guarantee that there will be only one enterprise in the market. If in the case of the Post Offices the intention is to expand the results of the natural monopoly into multi-product enterprises, then it would be possible in theory to construct the case in which the PO while producing the mix of services at minimum cost, would require that market entry by new enterprises be regulated in such a way as to eliminate destructive competition. But our examination of the operational conditions and the organizational structure of the POs has enabled us to make the point that the analysis of multi-product enterprises is hardly relevant to the problem of mail which is the case of the legal monopoly. A more convincing justification of the legal monopoly derives from the fact that the State has imposed at least two operational constraints on the Post Office; the service that has to be provided throughout the whole nation and uniform pricing, or pricing independent of mileage. These two restrictions make it possible that in some locations and especially in cities the price covers also part of the cost of the service to other areas, especially rural districts. It would then be possible for a private company not handicapped by the above constraints, to charge a lower price and to make a profit in low cost areas. That this is the principal reason for the legal monopoly is indirectly confirmed by the fact that the kind of "creaming-off' the market practised by private enterprises is exactly the same as what would happen if they took over an area of high density of population, especially in guaranteeing the service between two large urban centers that are relatively close to each other. It was not a random choice that the first couriers began their operations on the Milan-Turin "route". But if uniform pricing and universality of service throughout the nation are the seasons given for creating the legal monopoly, then if they are abolished it would be possible to remove that monopoly and in this way free the services from the inefficiencies that dog it. There arises, however, a concern linked to the reasons that could be hidden behind uniform pricing and the obligation to provide the service throughout the nation. In both cases there are positive external effects which could justify these restrictions on the behaviour of an enterprise. There are positive external effects in having a single service throughout the nation with the guarantee that every center and citizen however far-off will be linked in at reasonable prices. There is also an external impact of a distributive nature in uniform pricing which can be arrived at if the postal service is seen as an essential service for social life and one to which all citizens must have access at uniform price. These external effects can not be safeguarded by a State postal system based only on market forces. It would, then, be best to put the service into the hands of a State-owned enterprise. But a state monopoly able to defend these external effects, carries another kind of cost with it, namely the cost of a badly run service. This comes about because monopoly lacks the package of incentives which are typical in a competitive use of resources and also because a state-monopoly can come about through channels other than the protection of external effects. Monopoly can, in fact, be deliberately

41 created and legally protected by one or two interest groups not in an effort to improve the efficiency of the economic system but as a means for capturing income positions to the detriment of part or all of the citizen-body. It follows, then, that a state-owned monopoly because of the forces that ensure its survival is marred by allocative inefficiencies which are themselves the very reason for its existence. In such a context the debate on de-nationalization of companies providing public services takes on a clear character of political choice between the distributive consequences that characterize private production and the same consequences found in public production. Certainly, the best course would be if the postal services func tioned exactly as they are organized because the argument based on the external effects that derive from an integrated and universal service is a valid one in favour of the legal monopoly. But to get them working in a satisfactory way seems to be an impossible task given the motives and interests that are nested inside state-monopoly. Nevertheless, a comparison of data on efficiency in the Post Offices of European countries shows that very different levels of service quality can always exist inside the structures of a state-owned enterprise. The English may not be fully satisfied with their postal service and may complain about its slowness: but what would we in Italy say if our postal service could guarantee a day-after delivery for 80% of mail instead of the actual 17%? However, even when it has been demonstrated that levels of enhanced efficiency are possible inside state-owned enterprises, it does not mean that it is either easy or even possible to find the formula for realizing those improvements. What we have is a situation where the choice - in this case between state monopoly and private management of the postal service - is always second best in the sense that in any case something will be sacrificed and at the same time it is the only choice possible. In the present situation of many post offices, it is likely that liberalization is the only instrument that will reduce the power of pressure groups that have embedded themselves in the legal monopoly and have made a system of inefficiencies structural. This will have a price in loss of external positive effects in a nationally integrated system but to compensate these there should be a recovery of efficiency resulting in a major improvement in the service. Finally, it must be borne in mind that the monopoly of postal services is being eroded by technological innovation in commu nications. In recent years many substitute mailing systems have been developed (fax, telematic post) which are beyond the pale of monopoly. It is not difficult to envisage further developments in these systems and that they will eventually become essential aspects of everyday life and almost completely crowd out paper mail as we know it today. But in that prospect, many of the functions and importance of external effects will be lost which are now a barrier to the liberalization of the postal service. These effects, such as an integrated communications network and a service open to everyone, at present characterize the telephone system and in prospect will characterize the communications services based on the telephone network. In this context of ongoing change the proposals of the forthcoming European Community's "Green Paper" on postal services that suggest maintaining the legal monopoly on mail seem more the work of a combination of interests surrounding the state-monopoly than a contribution to improving the organizational structures in preparation for the changes already in progress. * * * **
