MONCORPS pp-^-Si Aujourd'hui, la holding est un instrument économique, financier et juridique utilisé dans la plupart des pays, dont ceux de la Communauté Européenne. Mais elle n'a pas toujours de définition légale. Le terme "holding" provient de l'anglais "to hold", qui signifie détenir. A partir de cette constatation, on peut donc définir la holding, comme une société dont le but est de détenir des participations, sous quelque forme que ce soit, dans une ou plusieurs sociétés, en vue de les contrôler. Il est important de noter que la holding, dans la plupart des systèmes juridiques actuels n'est pas un concept juridique, mais économique. Autrement dit, bien souvent, il n'existe pas de statut type de la holding. Elle prend la forme des sociétés classiques prévues dans chaque législation nationale. Ce caractère économique prédominant est directement lié à l'objet même de la holding : elle ne commercialise rien, mais a essentiellement un but financier, même si elle adopte en règle générale, les statuts d'une société commerciale. Les motivations qui président à l'adoption de cet instrument qu'est la holding démontrent parfaitement que l'on s'éloigne là des sociétés commerciales traditionnelles. En effet, la holding à usage national présente les avantages suivants : ­ L'entreprise familiale est particulièrement sujette à "l'éclatement des titres". Lorsqu'il s'agit de mettre en place une succession, il arrive bien souvent qu'un ou plusieurs des héritiers refusent de continuer l'exploitation, et préfèrent céder leurs titres. Si les héritiers qui désirent continuer l'exploitation créent une holding, ils y apportent leurs titres, et à partir du moment où la holding détient 50 % des parts de la société entrant dans la succession, elle la contrôle. ­ La holding peut être utilisée dans le but de bénéficier de ce que l'on appelle "l'effet de levier financier" . Bien souvent, une holding contracte des emprunts afin d'assurer le financement des prises de participations qui définissent son objet. En outre, nous le verrons, une holding ne supporte pas ou peu d'impôt sur les dividendes. Dès lors, les bénéfices pourront être employés librement pour le remboursement de ces emprunts. Ce système permet donc à la holding d'emprunter plus, et donc d'acheter plus de titres. Nous sommes donc bien loin de l'intérêt commercial qui définit les sociétés classiques. ­ De même, le système des holdings successives ou de la "chaîne de holding" permet avec un minimum de fonds et par l'intermédiaire de plusieurs holdings, d'obtenir une participation majoritaire dans une société. La holding permet également de "centraliser" des participations dans plusieurs sociétés qui ont des activités totalement différentes et donc, de les regrouper au sein d'une structure juridique unique. Dès lors, l'autonomie de ces sociétés est préservée, mais c'est la holding qui définit la politique du groupe. De même, la holding peut favoriser des flux financiers entre ces différentes sociétés, les produits des dividendes de l'une servant à "éponger" les déficits d'une autre. ­ La holding utilisée dans un contexte international fait apparaître des avantages considérables tels que l'optimisation des mouvements de dividendes perçus par la holding et redistribués par celle­ci à ses actionnaires non­résidents, l'exonération des plus­values réalisées à 1 occasion de la cession des titres de sociétés étrangères, et plus généralement, le bénéfice des convention fiscales internationales.

43 L'on notera en outre, que la plupart des montages juridiques internationaux faisant intervenir une holding, sont basés sur trois pays : la France, les Pays-Bas et le Luxembourg. Il est donc intéressant d'aborder le régime juridique et fiscal des holdings dans ces trois pays, qui font véritablement figure de pays-pilotes ou de référence en la matière. CARACTERISTIQUES GENERALES JURIDIQUES ET FISCALES La France Il n'existe en France ni définition légale ni statut type de la holding. En pratique, les holdings sont souvent constituées sous forme de sociétés anonymes, et détiennent des participations dans des sociétés d'exploitation qui sont, elles aussi, des sociétés anonymes. Pourtant, la holding en France peut prendre des formes diverses : société civile, société en commandite par actions, société en commandite simple, société en nom collectif, SARL ou société anonyme. Dans un tout autre contexte, la holding est utilisée en France par les salariés souhaitant racheter le capital de la société qui les emploie. En France, les holdings doivent juridiquement se distinguer : - des "compagnies financières" qui prennent également la forme de sociétés commerciales et qui, comme les holdings ont pour objet la prise de participations, mais qui contrôlent exclusivement des établissements de crédit, et non pas des sociétés commerciales traditionnelles; - des "sociétés d'investissement" qui n'ont pas pour objectif la prise de participations dans d'autres sociétés afin de les contrôler, mais pour de s'assurer des placements fructueux. Notons enfin qu'il existe plusieurs types de holdings en France, chaque type correspondant à un objectif bien précis : - Les "holdings de famille" sont constituées pour assurer à la fois une succession bien organisée permettant de conserver l'intégrité de la société de famille en évitant la vente des titres à des personnes étrangères au groupe familial, et une succession fiscalement sure, puisque le montage permet de trouver les fonds nécessaires au paiement des droits de succession. - Les "holdings de rachat" sont utilisées pour deux types d'opérations : - soit elles sont utilisées lorsqu'il s'avère nécessaire d'atténuer l'endettement des acheteurs : dans ce cas, l'emprunt est remboursé par les dividendes de la société rachetée, mais la charge fiscale est diminuée du fait qu'elle pèse sur la société bénéficiaire qui est une holding soumise à l'Impôt sur les sociétés, puisqu'il y a dès lors application du régime des sociétés mères et filiales ; - soit elle est utilisée dans le cadre du rachat d'une entreprise par ses salariés. - Les "holdings financières" ont pour objectif de regrouper un certain nombre d'entreprises exerçant leurs activités dans différents domaines, et de faire jouer de façon efficace la technique du levier" financier ou juridique exposé plus haut. Sur le plan fiscal, la France est sans aucun doute une juridiction intéressante pour la mise en place de holdings intermédiaires. Cet intérêt est principalement dû au régime des "sociétés mères et filiales" qui prévoit une exemption d'impôt pour les dividendes perçus par la société mère. Si, il y a encore peu de temps, la France ne possédait pas de statut particulier relatif aux holdings, l'article 28 de la loi de Finances du 29 décembre 1989 prévoit, au moins sur le plan fiscal, des dispositions spécifiques pour les holdings détenant des participations étrangères. Par contre, sur les autres plans, la holding est considérée comme une société classique et bénéficie donc des traités bilatéraux. Le Luxembourg Le Luxembourg, contrairement à la France et aux Pays-Bas, non seulement connaît depuis fort longtemps la notion de holding, mais encore en donne une définition légale. En effet, le Luxembourg a adopté une législation en la matière à savoir la loi du 31 juillet 1929, complétée par un amendement du 12 juillet 1977. Mais la législation luxembourgeoise n'est pas allée jusqu'à prévoir un statut type de la holding. Par conséquent, une holding luxembourgeoise se voit contrainte d'adopter une structure de société commerciale : Société anonyme, SARL, société en nom collectif, société en commandite simple ou par action, et société coopérative. Sans avoir de statut-type, la holding doit tout de même se conformer à un certain nombre de règles issues de la loi de 1929, et qui lui sont propres. Il existe en réalité deux types de holdings au Luxembourg, et qui sont toutes deux réglementées : la holding traditionnelle issue de la loi de 1929, et la holding ordinaire appelée également "société de participation financière" (SOPARFI) régie par l'arrêté Grand <îucal du 24 décembre 1990.

44 Concernant la holding traditionnelle, celle-ci est définie par la loi du 31 juillet 1929, de la façon suivante : "sera considérée comme société holding toute société luxembourgeoise qui a pour objet exclusif la prise de participations, sous quelque forme que ce soit, dans d'autres entreprises luxembourgeoises ou étrangères, et la gestion ainsi que la mise en valeur de ces participations, de manière qu'elle n'ait pas d'activité industrielle propre et qu'elle ne tienne pas un établissement commercial ouvert au public". Cette définition de la holding luxembourgeoise interdit donc à cette dernière d'avoir une quelconque activité industrielle ou commerciale. Il est dès lors logique de requalifier une holding lorsqu'elle tait acquisition d'un fonds de commerce, de know-how, de modèles et de dessins ou d'un immeuble ne constituant pas les bureaux de la société. Sont également incompatibles avec l'activité d'une holding, les participations dans des sociétés en nom collectif, des sociétés en commandite simple et des sociétés civiles. Enfin, une holding ne peut tenir un établissement ouvert au public, ni gérer portefeuilles ou avoirs pour le compte d'un tiers. Toutefois, ces interdictions sont tempérées. Ainsi, la holding peut faire l'acquisition de marques de fabrique, de brevets, ou de concessions de licences d'exploitation. Si la participation dans des sociétés civiles est incompatible avec le statut de holding, cette dernière peut toutefois prendre des participations dans des sociétés civiles dont l'objet est de détenir des participations qui pourraient être détenues directement par la holding. La holding traditionnelle est exonérée non seulement d'impôt sur les dividendes provenant de ses filiales mais également d'impôt sur les redistributions et d'une manière générale de tout impôt sur les sociétés. Seul un droit d'apport de 1 % à la constitution et en cas d'augmentation de capital doit être versé ainsi qu'une souscription annuelle égale à 0,20 % de la valeur des actions. En revanche, la holding traditionnelle est exclue du champs d'application des conventions de double imposition ratifiées par le Luxembourg. Les holdings ordinaires ou SOPARFI, ne bénéficient pas d'une définition légale particulière. Dès lors, juridiquement, elles sont limitées par les mêmes incompatibilité que la holding issue de la loi de 1929, et de façon globale, leur activité doit s'en tenir exclusivement à la prise de participation dans d'autres sociétés. Holding traditionnelle et SOPARFI ont donc la même définition, le même statut juridique et la même forme de société commerciale. Seulement, la holding ordinaire bénéficie d'un régime fiscal différent. En effet, il s'agit d'une société ayant un statut commercial à laquelle s'appliquent les règles normales d'imposition sur le revenu : Impôt sur le revenu au taux de 33 %, exemption des dividendes pour les participations supérieures à 10 % ou à 50.000.000 Francs luxembourgeois, application des traités. Les Pays-Bas Les holdings aux Pays-Bas ne font l'objet d'aucune définition légale précise et ne se voient pas appliquer de statut particulier. Certes la holding doit avoir pour objet exclusif la prise de participations dans d'autres sociétés néerlandaises ou étrangères, mais il n'existe pas là non plus de statut-type. Dès lors, la holding peut prendre la forme soit d'une "Naamloze Vennootschap" (NV), soit d'une "Besloten Vennootschap" (BV). La NV est une société proche de la société anonyme française. Sa formation requiert au moins un actionnaire, et son capital minimum est fixé à 100.000 Dfl divisé en actions cessibles. La BV, qui s'apparente à la SARL française, suit les mêmes règles que la NV, sauf en ce qui concerne le capital minimum. Celui de la BV est fixé à 40.000 Dfl. En outre, les actions de la BV, contrairement à la NV, ne peuvent être au porteur. Fiscalement, on peut remarquer que contrairement à la France et au Luxembourg qui ont, durant les trois dernières années, pris des dispositions afin de rendre les holdings plus performantes et plus concurrentielles, les Pays-Bas n'ont adopté qu'une disposition en faveur des holdings qui annule la condition de détention liée à l'exemption de plus-values en cas de vente d'actions. Par ailleurs, d'autres amendements ont été introduits dans la législation néerlandaise qui ont tendance à limiter certains avantages et donc à affaiblir la position des Pays-Bas dans le domaine des holdings. Malgré tout, la holding néerlandaise reste une référence en la matière et continue à être très utilisée. La clé du régime est, comme pour la France, un système d'exemption des dividendes versés par les filiales accompagné d'autres mesures qui seront développées plus loin. Enfin, la holding néerlandaise étant assujettie à la loi normale et n'étant donc pas limitée dans ses activités, bénéficie de l'application des conventions fiscales ratifiées par les Pays-Bas. * * * **

45 ( / θ) WEST V —' EUROPEAN POLITICS Volume 14 Number 4 October 1991 if The Internationalisation of Business and Domestic Class Compromises: A Four Country Study PAULETTE KURZER This article examines the impact of international business on the kind of class compromises that evolved and characterised many West European societies until the late 1970s. It raises the question of why class compromises endured longer in Austria and Sweden than in Belgium and the Netherlands. The argument is that domestic business in Austria and Sweden has fewer alliances with international capital and is, therefore, in a sense less integrated in world markets than those in Belgium and the Netherlands. The conclusion of the article, based upon recent trends, points out that the differences between the four coun­ tries appear to be rapidly disappearing. Most studies on corporatism, social partnerships or class compromises compare the structural attributes of organised labour. Variables such as the degree of centralisation and concentration of trade unions, the electoral strength of the social democratic party, the interaction between party and trade unions, and the relationship between individual unions and their federation leadership are the starting point for most writings on variations in class compromises, and their subsequent survival or demise. Occasional­ ly, the actions and organisation of capital are mentioned because of the influence of business on the strategic behaviour of labour.' Nevertheless, it is fair to say that a disproportionate number of publications trace the fate of class compromises through the actions and strategic objectives of labour. In turn, its actions and perceptions are informed by organisational resources, the balance of power within society, and the overall economic context. The purpose of this article is not to deny that certain structural deter­ minants of organised labour help account for the presence or absence of class compromises. Rather, it will raise one salient question that has not IH

46 yet been adequately addressed in the current literature. Why have wage concessions not resulted in an investment recovery in many European countries during the 1980s? Coercive or voluntary incomes policies, coupled with a notable decline in industrial militancy, marked the direction of economic policy in many European democracies. These policies did not, however, have the expected impact, with the result that unemployment remains extraordinarily high in some countries. Admittedly, the question of why wage concessions no longer generate jobs can be adequately ad dressed only by examining a large variety of economic, institutional, and historical factors. This article concentrates only on the structural characteristics of manufacturing capital and especially its degree of internationalisation and mobility. The argument is guided by the following proposition: leading business actors in different countries have created multiple partnerships with foreign corporations abroad and have become, in the process, global actors with modest stakes in the developments of the domestic economy and with few bonds to national governments or organised labour. 2 The Keynesian assumption on which the postwar settlement was built claimed that wage concessions translated into increased investments and stable growth. Government and organised labour accepted this association between investments and economic growth by moderating wage demands in the present in return for better standard of living in the future. But this link, if it ever existed, describes the investment and growth cycles of relatively 'closed' economies of the 1950s and 1960s but is no longer ap plicable to the present decade of high capital mobility and rapid financial innovations. Since the trend toward globalisation varies across nations and over time, it is vital to re-examine the validity of theories of class compromises by assessing the actual as opposed to the expected results of policies favoured by these theories. In order to address this question, the article examines the economic activities and investment orientation of leading actors in the business communities of four small, open economies: Austria, Belgium, the Netherlands, and Sweden. The principal contention of this article is that workers and their representative organisations in these four countries have proven to be equally prepared to grant concessions to management and government. Labour strategies, therefore, do not diverge sufficiently fully to account for the different success rates of the respective govern ments in maintaining the essential elements of the social exchange intact, namely by persuading labour to substitute wage increases for job security. Not so long ago, each of these four European democracies established social institutions and procedures to further social exchange between labour and capital and conformed more or less to the corporatist typology. 3 Economic policies of the past decade also show increasing convergences in that governments of the small states brought down wage costs, in one fashion or another, to promote export growth. To be sure, the final results differ dramatically. In two countries - Austria and Sweden - wage con cessions, underpinning a visible recovery in profitability had the desired effect of raising investments and preventing further job losses. In the second pair of countries - Belgium and the Netherlands - fiscal con servatism and wage ceilings restored profit margins but did not lead to greater investment activity or a considerable drop in unemployment. This is not because governments or labour refused to lighten the wage cost burden or failed to build a more hospitable business climate. This article intends to comple ment, not to deny, the arguments about the impact of the organisational strength of labour and leftist government programmes on investment decisions and labour market trends. CONCLUDING REMARKS The growth cycle faltered and a series of financial scandals rocked Austria in the late 1980s. Denationalisation and internationalisation are now the key words. Austria submitted its application for membership in the EC in autumn 1989 and though Brussels is not yet ready to rule on new member ships, the writing is on the wall. Privatisation has moved slowly but it will surely pick up once EC membership is a true possibility. Reservations with regard to selling to foreigners will also subside and there should be no doubt that economic management will look very different in the 1990s once Austria has become a full Community participant. 61 Sweden has stumbled into a severe economic crisis, with high inflation, low productivity, and large current account deficits. The cure, it seems, is to follow in the EC's footsteps by trimming the public sector and im plementing tough monetary and fiscal measures. The new Swedish tune is partially due to the increasing integration of markets, with capital free to cross borders, and that limits the extent to which Sweden can pursue policies different from the rest of Europe. With the social democrats hesitating to take drastic steps, Swedish business has responded by multiplying its foreign direct investment and the annual rate reached $7.5 billion in 1990, or ten times as much as five years ago. 62 This article must, therefore, conclude that domestic structures and various arrangements in diverse European countries have increasingly con verged. What is left is to explain why the timing and pace of the disap pearances of class compromises differed. That question has pre-occupied writings on political economy which, however, tend to focus on labour market characteristics or forms of collective action.

49 This article has argued that one variable, frequently overlooked in the regular political economy literature, could possibly illuminate the paradox of why wage moderation and other forms of 'responsible' behaviour on the part of labour and governments have nonetheless failed to induce firms to continue to invest. This variable is the degree to which domestic firms have sought alliances with foreign capital. It is for this reason that in countries such as Belgium and the Netherlands the connection between domestic investment incentives and the capital-owners' investment decisions is simply severed. In turn, the sharper contradiction between the national or domestic structures of decision making and the international structure of capital accumulation is attributed to the combined effects of early participation in European integration and each business community's specific historical traits. In Sweden and Austria, historical origins of leading firms in the business community differ from those in Belgium and the Netherlands while non- EC membership helped preserve the national roots of those firms. In Austria, non-EC membership made it possible to continue to treat the state-owned enterprises as policy instruments in the fight against growing unemployment and regional imbalances. In Sweden, on the other hand, a closed financial system allowed national firms to invest abroad but prevented foreigners from penetrating the domestic market and from competing with critical industrial sectors or firms at home. Nationalised holding companies in Austria or strict exchange and capital controls in Sweden succeeded in decelerating or modifying the financial and economic integration of their respective home markets and contributed to the better economic record in the 1980s. On a broader level, this article also questions the existence of a relation ship between a country's small market size and the actions of business to compensate for a limited home market and export dependency. A descrip tive comparison of the international strategies of firms in the four countries demonstrates in effect no relationship between economic size, foreign economic policies, and more importantly, the evolution of business interests and its relationship with international markets or capital. It is safe to conclude that the size of the domestic market not only fails to predict the likelihood of consensual corporatist arrangements with its corresponding association of coherent and efficient policy intervention but also challenges the widely held assumption concerning smaller European democracies' parallel experiences in the international political economy. It would be more fruitful to differentiate European countries according to EC or non-EC membership and attribute their respective vulnerability to international disturbances to that distinction. At least, that would go some ways in accounting for the differences in multinationalisation and in assessing the impact of international capital mobility on domestic arrangements such as class compromises. * * * **

51 TOWARDS INTERNATIONALISATION An introduction by Michael Blair, General Counsel, Securities and Investments Board T he last few years have seen an increasing internationalisation of securities and other investment business. The importance attached in the European Community to the Second Banking Coordination Directive and the (draft) Investment Services Directive are good examples of this. Ten years ago there were no memoranda of understanding about cooperation between securities regulators, but these are now fast spreading bilater ally across the globe. Five trends are now clearly discernible, some of them proceeding faster than others. The first trend is increasing use by individual investors of international instruments. In the United Kingdom, and perhaps elsewhere, the pro portion of individual investors as direct users of stock markets appears to be falling. Individuals' share in share ownership fell from 28 per cent in 1981 to 21 per cent in 1989 and their share in the value of the UK turnover in domestic equities fell from 27 per cent to 17 per cent over that decade (source: Stock Exchange Quality of Markets Review). Nonetheless, the substantial growth in the size of the life assurance and unit trust sectors over the same period suggests that the main overall change is a switch towards collectivisation of the individual investors' portfolios, and out of individual holdings. And the exposure of the average individual investors' portfolio (whether collectivised or not) to overseas securities has substantially increased over the period. Some 10 years ago exposure to the Pacific Basin, or to the Far East generally, was much less than it is today. The second trend is more use of overseas mar kets by investors. The latest UK Quality of Markets Review shows, for instance, that overseas investors' share of UK equity turnover has risen fourfold in the last decade to reach 20 per cent. 55 per cent of the (London) business in overseas equities is now carried on for overseas investors. So the use of the London market for international professionals has greatly increased over the last 10 years. The third relates to increasing use of deriva tives, not only domestically, but on the international plane. The increasing number of international instruments offered by LIFFE and the steady vol ume growth of trading in most of them is one good example. Cross-border buying and selling of con tracts is another. Partly this is because of increasing expertise in derivative instruments, and increasing confidence in their use among institutional investors in the UK and elsewhere. Part of the growth is also attributable to the undoubted utility of derivatives for concentrating on the specific indicator in which the investor is interested, and for hedging out other, unwanted, risks. The fourth concerns cooperation among regula tors. This really began with the fashioning of infor mal arrangements for mutual assistance and the exchange of information in the capital adequacy field and in relation to enforcement. The recently restructured US/UK Memorandum of Under-stand ing is a good example of the latter. And in the former case, UK financial supervision regulators have established a substantial network of arrangements for international cooperation in relation to routine prudential oversight of branch institutions. More recently, there has been a discernible move towards mutuel inter-reliance on a more substantive footing. The prime example of this, so far, is the transferable passport provisions in the draft Investment Services Directive of the EC. Earlier examples include the arrangements negotiated between the UK deriva tives regulators and the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission which allow specified UK firms to undertake transactions for US clients on UK mar kets largely on the strength of a UK authorisation. The fifth trend relates to international conver gence. Increasing interdependence within and between the industry and regulators, and the increasing internationalisation of the business itself, is leading, gradually but unmistakably, to a greater degree of similarity in the content of different regu latory regimes. One simple example of this is the adoption by the International Organisation of Securities Commissions (at Santiago in Chile in 1990) of some 'International Conduct of Business Principles'. These follow some early work in France, the United Kingdom and elsewhere, and demon strate a common standard for (and similar approach to) high level obligations of those involved in the conduct of investment business. Some trace of these IOSCO principles now appears in the draft Investment Services Directive. This publication provides interested observers with precise and will informed detail about the extent of these developments. * * * **

Nevertheless, leverage finance ­ defined broadly as any element of external debt fi­ nancing to help fund a transaction ­ has pía ved a sig­ nificant role in the expanding European m&a mar­ ket and no doubt will continue to do so. Leverage finance for crossborder acquisitions brings with it additional legal and com­ mercial issues which reflect the continuing differ­ ences across Europe despite moves to harmonize practices. These issues apply equally to the rare ex­ amples of mul ticountry leveraged bu vou ts, I ike A vis Europe or Swedish Match, and to the vast majority of conventional crossborder takeovers reiving to a greater or lesser extent on bank borrowings. This article focuses upon a number of the issues raised and, in particular, those which may influence the structures within which leverage finance can be utilized for an agreed cash acquisition of a limited liability company or group of companies. There is no preconceived uniform structure and approach to leveraged acquisitions throughout Europe ­ the varied national require­ ments and cultural differences necessitate a flexible outlook together with an understanding of the com­ mercial and economic rationale for each transaction if a feasible structure is to be found. The "ideal" structure As with any acquisition, the "ideal" structure will seek to meet the immediate and future requirements of the seller and the buyer. These requirements will often be in conflict, result­ ing in a compromise structure, but the leverage element adds an additional interested party ­ the banks ­ with their own particular requirements. The banks' position is unlikely to dictate the structure but must be balanced against all other financial and commercial concerns. The following key objectives will need to be addressed and, if possible, met: • minimizing the tax liability of the seller; • maximizing relief for acquisition costs, e.g. ­ by offsetting financing costs against taxable profits; ­ bv claiming full tax depreciation of the purchase price through stepping up asset values; • maximizing the efficiency of the extraction of profits, e.g. ­ by preserving any tax benefits; ­ by minimizing withholding taxes and corporate taxes on future crossborder interest, dividend and royalty flows; • creating a flexible structure for the future (taking into account such matters as possible reorganiza­ tions and future disposals); • minimizing currency risks for the buyer; • integration with existing businesses; • operating an effective debt structure, e.g. ­ location of debt to match local requirements; ­ efficient servicing of interest payments; ­ adequate security for banks. The use of leverage finance im­ pacts on a number of the above issues, raising both some practical and legal considerations. The key questions to focus on are: where is the debt needed? who will be the lenders? and what security will be available for the lenders?

Conclusion It is clear that the pattern of technical change and political initiatives has rendered the idea of the public utility far less coherent than in the past. The breach in the utility concept has its causes in a variety of changes. These are reflected in market restructuring, the technological dynamics of the indus tries, and variations in policy approaches. EC activities have served to consolidate changing perceptions and to impose them politically in coun tries which have clung to older regimes or who have implemented only modest reforms. A mixture of motives, at once deregulatory and integration ist, has driven the EC to engage in its intervention. It appears that the deregulatory (or pro-competition) motivation is strongest at the moment. An overarching vision has been imposed on very different sectors with the danger that divergences in these sectors have not been fully addressed. Although consumers and suppliers are pressing for greater access both to the electricity and telecommunications systems, their reasons for doing so, and the market conditions they face, are quite different. To suggest that the telecommunications experience proves that similar changes can be implemented in other utility industries by abstracting from their shared characteristics is to ignore the differences between the two sectors and particularly the divergences in the sectors over the past 20 years. The telecommunications industry is well on the way to abandoning the utility model, but even here trends suggest that the utility concept still influences policy with regard to universal service and the terms of network interconnection among future competitors. It is by no means clear that the ESI is moving substantially away from its public utility status. In the UK, where the shift in organization has been greatest (and which some in the Commission appear to use as an exemplar to the rest of the EC), it is clear

56 that the industry has retained its monopoly character is some key aspects, and monopolistic or oligopolistic practices prevail in other ostensibly com petitive areas. The persistence of these elements does not mean that there have been no benefits from the UK experiment, only that it is still an experiment and that it is too early to judge its success, let alone use it as a model for change across Europe. Moreover, in neither industry is it likely that market forces will prevail untrammelled. Not only does competition present several regulatory dilem mas (in terms of equity and efficiency concerns) but the wider agenda of industrial strategy and energy policy is likely to persist, at national and Community levels. It may be that the future of these industries lies in their reconfiguration at EC level. Certainly the Commission appears to be redefining utility status in a European context with its increasing focus on 'infrastructures'. As noted above, in 1990 the Council of the European Communities adopted a resolution that 'special priority should be given . .. to the development and interconnection of trans-European networks. . .'. 2b The Commission regards trans-European networks as necessary to the creation of a truly internal market. It has identified areas in which the utility industries have yet to develop effective Europe-wide linkages. Yet, as noted, this approach seeks to enhance cooperation among utilities at the very moment when other EC policies aim to introduce greater competition. In summary, EC policy is bringing new issues to bear on all member states. The Commission is keen to introduce elements of competition but seeks also to ensure that economies of scale are achieved. This implies intervention in the structure and conduct of both the electricity and telecommunications industries. The reshaping of utility markets is taking place in the face of rapid restructuring in the USA and Japan, with whom European utilities must compete, often before the Commission's restructur ing plans have been fully implemented. The contradiction between the Commission's market-led goals and a more interventionist strategy illustrates a dilemma facing policy makers: whether to go for the benefits of competition or to foster competitiveness. Some countries have made clear which aspect they are pursuing, others are trying to strike a balance which errs on the side of intervention.
